Kaye Chosen To Sit On SC
BY ETHAN RARICK
Seth Kaye replaced Colin
Flynn as Student Council
representative Wednesday night,
after having been chosen on
Sunday by the junior class officers as Flynn's successor.
Flynn, who will not be a fulltime student this semester,
resigned from the council two
weeks ago.
Kaye told the News-Letter
earlier this week that he will run
for re-election as a senior class
representative.
Although he had not previously run for a seat on the
council, Kaye said that he applied for this position because
"there are many long-time decisions the council will be involved in, especially in terms of
housing and educational
policy."
Accordingly, Kaye said he
wanted to serve on the Housing
and Education committees.
After Wednesday night's meet-

ing, Student Council President
Doug Fellman tentatively appointed Kaye to the Education
and Legal Rights committees.
According to Fellman, Kaye
was not placed on the Housing
Committee because there are
already seven Student Council
members on that committee.
Speaking on the "long-term
decisions" he is most interested
in, Kaye expressed two major
concerns on educational policy.
"I think the office of Advising and Counseling has got to
be strengthened, especially in
pre-law adv;smg," Kaye said.
Additionally, Kaye said he
believes that there needs to be
more communication between
students and their faculty
advisers.
On housing issues, Kaye said
he fears that as the economy
improves, a co-op conversion
trend may hit the apartment
buildings surrounding Hopkins, making it harder for
students to find housing.

Kaye noted that a trend of
co-op conversions has already
hit New York and Washington,
and that it was just reaching
Baltimore when the recession
began, causing the trend to
slow. Kaye said that the "most
feasible" solution to this problem would be for the University
to buy an apartment building
near campus, but that this
creates "community problems."
Kaye also suggested that the
University work with the city
and state governments to
strengthen anti-co-op laws.
Although he said that he
does not believe that the
University will ever be able to
house all students, Kaye said he
thinks the University should attempt to ensure that students do
not "lose contact with the
campus."
"I think the University
should strive to accommodate
[in University-owned housing]
as many students as possible,"
Kaye said.

A massive restructuring of
the federal financial aid system
resulting in a multitude of cuts
may be in store for college
students if President Ronald
Reagan's recent budget proposals are passed by Congress.
In an attempt to "ensure that
parents and students assume
the primary responsibility" of
paying for education, Reagan is
advocating the elimination of a
number of grant programs and
the implementation of a new
method of allocating federal
funds.
The administration's new
proposal would require all college students to pay at least 40
percent of their educational
costs before they qualify for a
federal grant. Those students
who qualify would be expected

study and loan programs, allowing them to receive grants
only if other sources of aid proved insufficient.

aid system considers the Pell

aid, with work study and loans
as supplements. So, in effect,
the Reagan proposal is a reversal of the present priorities for
allocating funds.

University, for example, sponsors a program where selected

To improve Hopkins' limited
program, the committee is discussing a three-fold merit-based
program, offering students the
possibility of scholarships,
work or loans on the basis of
past academic performance.
Such a program would be considered an addition to the existing need-based aid system.
The establishment of an institutional (merit-based) work
program would offer job placement on and off campus to all
students, regardless of their
financial need. It has also been
proposed that an alumni employment network be developed
to find jobs for students in the
community and the private sector, as well as within the
University, while the student is
in school.
Funding for such programs
should come from endowment
money. Members of the committee have suggested allocating
an annual amount of money
from the Capital Fund campaign.
In addition to any financial
benefits students would receive
from this institutional work
program, Financial Aid Director Susan Broadbent asserts
that such a program would also
help the faculty and University, as a whole, by utilizing
students' talents and attracting
higher caliber undergraduates.
According to Broadbent, President Steve Muller agrees that a
merit-based system would be
advantageous for the University. He objects, however, to lending to students on such a basis.
Moreover, he raises questions
about the morality of offering
student aid to those students
who do not demonstrate sufficient financial need. Faced with
these problems, the committee
will continue to consider the
possibilty of a merit-based
system.
